elements.content: Two complexes, [WS4Cu5I3(bbd)2] n (1) and [(WS4Cu3I)2(bbd)3] n ·n(DMF) (2), with one-dimensional polymeric chain structures containing hexanuclear and tetranuclear clusters linked by flexible 1,4-bis(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-1-yl)butane (bbd) ligands have been synthesized in facile one-pot reactions at room temperature, together with the molybdenum analogue of 2. The only significant difference in the syntheses of the two tungsten complexes is the 5:1 or 3:1 molar ratio of copper(I) to [WS4]2–, the other experimental factors being kept constant. The observed products reflect the stoichiometric Cu:W ratio used. All three complexes were characterized by IR and UV–vis spectroscopy, thermal and elemental analyses, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 contains an unusual and surprisingly unsymmetrical WS4Cu5I3 cluster in which five Cu atoms bridge all but one of the six S···S edges of the WS4 tetrahedron and the three I atoms all have different coordination modes (terminal, μ2 and μ3); it consists of two face-sharing WS3Cu3I distorted cubes, in one of which a Cu···I edge is opened up instead of being bonded, this Cu atom (shared by the two cubes) having an additional terminal iodo ligand. Complex 2 is the first reported example of a polymer containing (S=)MS3M′3X cubes linked by organic ligands; pairs of these cube clusters are connected by pairs of bbd ligands, and the (cluster)2(bbd)2 units are assembled into chains by single bbd bridges. In these and previously reported complexes, the bbd bridging ligand displays considerable flexibility, enabling it to support a range of discrete oligomeric and polymeric structures. X-ray powder diffraction shows that 2 is consistently obtained as a mixture of two polymorphs, and the same has been found for the corresponding molybdenum complex [(MoS4Cu3I)2(bbd)3] n ·n(DMF) (3), for which the second polymorph has been structurally characterized by single-crystal diffraction using synchrotron radiation. The two polymorphs have essentially identical polymer chain structures, with different packing arrangements of the chains and different symmetry properties.

The only significant difference in the syntheses of the two tungsten complexes is the 5:1 or 3:1 molar ratio of copper(I) to [WS4]2-, the other experimental factors being kept constant. The observed products reflect the stoichiometric Cu:W ratio used. All three complexes were characterized by IR and UV-vis spectroscopy, thermal and elemental analyses, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 contains an unusual and surprisingly unsymmetrical WS4Cu5I3 cluster in which five Cu atoms bridge all but one of the six S⋅⋅⋅S edges of the WS4 tetrahedron and the three I atoms all have different coordination modes (terminal, μ2 and μ3); it consists of two face-sharing WS3Cu3I distorted cubes, in one of which a Cu⋅⋅⋅I edge is opened up instead of being bonded, this Cu atom (shared by the two cubes) having an additional terminal iodo ligand. Complex 2 is the first reported example of a polymer containing (S=)MS3M'3X cubes linked by organic ligands; pairs of these cube clusters are connected by pairs of bbd ligands, and the (cluster)2(bbd)2 units are assembled into chains by single bbd bridges. In these and previously reported complexes, the bbd bridging ligand displays considerable flexibility, enabling it to support a range of discrete oligomeric and polymeric structures. The two polymorphs have essentially identical polymer chain structures, with different packing arrangements of the chains and different symmetry properties.

elements.content: Reaction of (NH4)2[WS4], CuI, and the ligand bbd having two pyrazole rings linked by a (CH2)4 chain gives different chain polymers depending on the W:Cu stoichiometry. One product contains an unusual unsymmetrical WS4Cu5I3 cluster in which S serves as μ3 and μ4 bridges, all three I atoms behave differently (terminal, μ2 and μ3), and Cu occurs in two different four-coordinate environments.

One product contains an unusual unsymmetrical WS4Cu5I3 cluster in which S serves as μ3 and μ4 bridges, all three I atoms behave differently (terminal, μ2 and μ3), and Cu occurs in two different four-coordinate environments.

elements.content: The study of self-assembled coordination polymers containing transition metal ions and flexible organic bridging ligands is an active area of study not only in applications to host–guest chemistry including gas storage, ion exchange, catalysis, and for the development of optical, magnetic and electronic devices, but also more fundamentally because of the observed diversity of fascinating structural motifs, ranging from finite (zero-dimensional) oligomers, through one- and two-dimensional polymeric chains and sheets, to three-dimensional networks. One of the interesting aspects of metal organic framework materials (MOFs) is the desire for a purposeful design of predictable networks rather than a serendipitous approach, so that these materials can be truly engineered with appropriate properties to suit particular applications. When flexible ligands are involved in designing supramolecular architectures, the predicted and the actual resulting topology of the framework of such compounds is affected by several factors including the nature of the solvent, any counterions present (both of these may play a templating role), and the metal-to-ligand ratio used in the synthesis. Furthermore, ligands containing a flexible backbone provide conformational freedom that generates even greater structural diversity than can be obtained with more rigid ligands, though this is likely to lead also to less predictability. So far, there have been only a few reports of supramolecular compounds with metal–sulfur clusters as secondary building units (SBUs). Much more effort is thus required in this direction to generate new heterometallic polymers and understand their topologies and detailed structures. At the same time, the chemistry of W/Mo–Cu–S heterothiometallic clusters has remained an active research area, because of their rich structural chemistry, potential applications in biological systems and as model compounds, possible gas adsorption properties, and their use in optoelectronic materials. They are available to crystal engineers as fundamental building blocks to design and construct new coordination polymers with interesting structures. Of particular interest are supramolecular arrays containing heterothiometallic clusters of [MS4]2– (M = W or Mo) ions with edge-bridging Cu(I) as SBUs (structural nodes) and flexible polydentate organic ligands as linkers. With regard to the metal center, the Cu(I) ion is a particularly well-suited cation for study, not only because it displays a variety of coordination numbers and coordination geometries without crystal field stabilization energy preferences, but also because it can associate in a range of bond strengths with a counterion such as iodide (and other halides and pseudohalides) which are then incorporated as an essential element of the resulting framework with different terminal and/or bridging coordination modes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The study of self-assembled coordination polymers containing transition metal ions and flexible organic bridging ligands is an active area of study not only in applications to host-guest chemistry including gas storage, ion exchange, catalysis, and for the development of optical, magnetic and electronic devices, but also more fundamentally because of the observed diversity of fascinating structural motifs, ranging from finite (zero-dimensional) oligomers, through one- and two-dimensional polymeric chains and sheets, to three-dimensional networks. One of the interesting aspects of metal organic framework materials (MOFs) is the desire for a purposeful design of predictable networks rather than a serendipitous approach, so that these materials can be truly engineered with appropriate properties to suit particular applications. When flexible ligands are involved in designing supramolecular architectures, the predicted and the actual resulting topology of the framework of such compounds is affected by several factors including the nature of the solvent, any counterions present (both of these may play a templating role), and the metal-to-ligand ratio used in the synthesis. Furthermore, ligands containing a flexible backbone provide conformational freedom that generates even greater structural diversity than can be obtained with more rigid ligands, though this is likely to lead also to less predictability. So far, there have been only a few reports of supramolecular compounds with metal-sulfur clusters as secondary building units (SBUs). Much more effort is thus required in this direction to generate new heterometallic polymers and understand their topologies and detailed structures. At the same time, the chemistry of W/Mo-Cu-S heterothiometallic clusters has remained an active research area, because of their rich structural chemistry, potential applications in biological systems and as model compounds, possible gas adsorption properties, and their use in optoelectronic materials. They are available to crystal engineers as fundamental building blocks to design and construct new coordination polymers with interesting structures. Of particular interest are supramolecular arrays containing heterothiometallic clusters of [MS4]2- (M = W or Mo) ions with edge-bridging Cu(I) as SBUs (structural nodes) and flexible polydentate organic ligands as linkers. With regard to the metal center, the Cu(I) ion is a particularly well-suited cation for study, not only because it displays a variety of coordination numbers and coordination geometries without crystal field stabilization energy preferences, but also because it can associate in a range of bond strengths with a counterion such as iodide (and other halides and pseudohalides) which are then incorporated as an essential element of the resulting framework with different terminal and/or bridging coordination modes.

elements.content: Although one MS4 tetrahedron can bind directly to M′ or M′–X units successively through its six S···S edges to give clusters with nuclearity up to 7, the possible bridging nature of X means that even more metal centers can in fact be accommodated around the MS4 2– core. There is thus potential for huge structural variety in this field of chemistry. As an illustration of this, we have carried out searches of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) for MS4 tetrahedra (with M restricted to Mo or W) having from 1 to 6 S···S edges bridged by any metal atom M′ to give structures in which the MS4M′ n clusters are not directly linked by sharing their constituent atoms to form a larger discrete or polymeric cluster. We find the following numbers of reported structures (counting only once any reports of the same structure or polymorphs): n = 1, 87; n = 2, 111; n = 3, 67; n = 4, 65; n = 5, 10; n = 6, 10. Note that two different isomeric arrangements are possible for edge-bridging in each of the cases where n = 2, 3, 4, or 5. No fewer than 22 different metals M′ occur in these structures, though the vast majority have M′ = Cu for n > 2, with M′ = Ag as second most common. It is particularly interesting that there are far fewer clusters in which five or six edges are bridged, and these are almost entirely restricted to copper-bridged complexes. The recent report by Zheng et al. of some polypyridyl-bridged 3D MOFs containing WS4Cu4 clusters as SBUs includes results that are not yet available in the released periodic CSD updates and thus adds a few further examples to the statistics given above; of particular importance is that this includes the first reported example of a polymeric structure incorporating a hexanuclear cluster WS4Cu5 in which five of the six S···S edges of the WS4 tetrahedron are bridged by metal atoms.

There is thus potential for huge structural variety in this field of chemistry. As an illustration of this, we have carried out searches of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) for MS4 tetrahedra (with M restricted to Mo or W) having from 1 to 6 S⋅⋅⋅S edges bridged by any metal atom M' to give structures in which the MS4M' n  clusters are not directly linked by sharing their constituent atoms to form a larger discrete or polymeric cluster. We find the following numbers of reported structures (counting only once any reports of the same structure or polymorphs): n = 1, 87; n = 2, 111; n = 3, 67; n = 4, 65; n = 5, 10; n = 6, 10. Note that two different isomeric arrangements are possible for edge-bridging in each of the cases where n = 2, 3, 4, or 5. No fewer than 22 different metals M' occur in these structures, though the vast majority have M' = Cu for n > 2, with M' = Ag as second most common. It is particularly interesting that there are far fewer clusters in which five or six edges are bridged, and these are almost entirely restricted to copper-bridged complexes. elements.content: So far, W/Mo–Cu–S coordination polymers with considerable observed structural diversity have been successfully assembled with [MS4Cu n ] (M = Mo, W; n = 2, 3, mainly 4, 5, or 6) cores and suitable organic linker ligands. Almost all of these compounds have been prepared by solvothermal reactions or by using preformed clusters as starting materials. However, heterothiometallic clusters containing the hexanuclear [MS4Cu5] core structure have not been observed in any polymeric systems prior to the work of Zheng et al. reported in 2012, and the few Cu5 examples identified in the above CSD searches are all monomeric with purely inorganic ligands except for one monomeric cluster containing monodentate pyridine ligands and one structure in which two clusters are linked by a bridging bidentate ligand.
elements.clean_text: So far, W/Mo-Cu-S coordination polymers with considerable observed structural diversity have been successfully assembled with [MS4Cu n ] (M = Mo, W; n = 2, 3, mainly 4, 5, or 6) cores and suitable organic linker ligands. Almost all of these compounds have been prepared by solvothermal reactions or by using preformed clusters as starting materials. However, heterothiometallic clusters containing the hexanuclear [MS4Cu5] core structure have not been observed in any polymeric systems prior to the work of Zheng et al. reported in 2012, and the few Cu5 examples identified in the above CSD searches are all monomeric with purely inorganic ligands except for one monomeric cluster containing monodentate pyridine ligands and one structure in which two clusters are linked by a bridging bidentate ligand.

elements.content: We are currently engaged in synthetic and structural studies of coordination polymers with flexible pyrazole-based ligands, Cu(I), and MS4 2– (M = W, Mo) metalloligands in a facile one-pot reaction at room temperature. Some successful experiments have shown that such ligands are able to generate new polymers with interesting structures. On the basis of this strategy, we have also been able to design and synthesize only the second neutral hexanuclear heterothiometallic polymer with a [WS4Cu5] cluster core, and another related polymer with tetranuclear [WS4Cu3] building blocks, at room temperature from [WS4]2–, Cu(I), and a flexible pyrazole-based ligand as starting materials, using an easy and versatile procedure. The observed structures reported here and their stoichiometries reflect, though they do not both precisely match, the reagent ratios chosen for their synthesis. In the case of the tetranuclear structure and of its molybdenum analogue, powder diffraction indicates the presence of two concurrent polymorphs, the second of which has been structurally characterized from the molybdenum system.
elements.clean_text: We are currently engaged in synthetic and structural studies of coordination polymers with flexible pyrazole-based ligands, Cu(I), and MS4 2- (M = W, Mo) metalloligands in a facile one-pot reaction at room temperature. Some successful experiments have shown that such ligands are able to generate new polymers with interesting structures. On the basis of this strategy, we have also been able to design and synthesize only the second neutral hexanuclear heterothiometallic polymer with a [WS4Cu5] cluster core, and another related polymer with tetranuclear [WS4Cu3] building blocks, at room temperature from [WS4]2-, Cu(I), and a flexible pyrazole-based ligand as starting materials, using an easy and versatile procedure. The observed structures reported here and their stoichiometries reflect, though they do not both precisely match, the reagent ratios chosen for their synthesis. In the case of the tetranuclear structure and of its molybdenum analogue, powder diffraction indicates the presence of two concurrent polymorphs, the second of which has been structurally characterized from the molybdenum system.

elements.content: All experiments were carried out in air. The starting materials were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification; the ligand bbd and (NH4)2[WS4] were prepared from them by published methods. Infrared spectra (4000–400 cm–1) were recorded from KBr disks with a BOMEN MB102 FT-IR spectrometer. Electronic spectra were recorded on a GBC Cintral 101 spectrophotometer from freshly made samples in DMF solution and covered the range 700–270 nm. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Thermo Finigan Flash EA 1120 CHN analyzer. Thermal analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer Diamond TG/DTA thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 between 50 and 800 °C under a dinitrogen atmosphere with a flow rate of 200 cm3 min–1. X-ray powder diffraction patterns were recorded on a Philips X’PertPro diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.54184 Å) in the 2θ range 5–50°.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All experiments were carried out in air. The starting materials were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification; the ligand bbd and (NH4)2[WS4] were prepared from them by published methods. Infrared spectra (4000-400 cm-1) were recorded from KBr disks with a BOMEN MB102 FT-IR spectrometer. Electronic spectra were recorded on a GBC Cintral 101 spectrophotometer from freshly made samples in DMF solution and covered the range 700-270 nm. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Thermo Finigan Flash EA 1120 CHN analyzer. Thermal analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer Diamond TG/DTA thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 between 50 and 800 °C under a dinitrogen atmosphere with a flow rate of 200 cm3 min-1. X-ray powder diffraction patterns were recorded on a Philips X'PertPro diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.54184 Å) in the 2θ range 5-50°.

elements.content: CuI (0.14 g, 0.72 mmol) was added to a yellow solution of (NH4)2[WS4] (0.05 g, 0.14 mmol) in DMF (15 mL). After being stirred for ca. 15 min, bbd (0.07 g, 0.28 mmol) was added to this solution, which was stirred for another 10 min at room temperature and filtered. Red single crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained from the freshly made sample in DMF, by leaving the filtrate to stand at room temperature for 2 days; they were collected and washed consecutively with small amounts of DMF, MeCN and Et2O, and dried in air (0.12 g, 57% based on W). Anal. calcd (%) for C28H44Cu5I3N8S4W: C 22.4, H 3.0, N 7.5; found: C 23.0, H 2.8, N 7.8.

After being stirred for ca. 15 min, bbd (0.07 g, 0.28 mmol) was added to this solution, which was stirred for another 10 min at room temperature and filtered. Red single crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained from the freshly made sample in DMF, by leaving the filtrate to stand at room temperature for 2 days; they were collected and washed consecutively with small amounts of DMF, MeCN and Et2O, and dried in air (0.12 g, 57% based on W). Anal. calcd (%) for C28H44Cu5I3N8S4W: C 22.4, H 3.0, N 7.5; found: C 23.0, H 2.8, N 7.8.

elements.content: CuI (0.08 g, 0.42 mmol) was added to a yellow solution of (NH4)2[WS4] (0.05 g, 0.14 mmol) in DMF (15 mL). After stirring for ca. 15 min, bbd (0.07 g, 0.28 mmol) was added to this solution, which was stirred for another 10 min at room temperature and filtered. Yellow-orange crystals of 2 were obtained by a method similar to that for complex 1 (0.09 g, 73% based on W). Anal. calcd (%) for C21H33Cu3IN6S4W·0.5C3H7NO: C 26.1, H 3.5, N 8.8; found: C 26.4, H 3.3, N 8.7.

elements.content: This compound was prepared in a manner similar to that for complex 2, but using (NH4)2[MoS4] (0.035 g, 0.14 mmol) instead of (NH4)2[WS4]. Very small, dark violet crystals of 3 suitable for X-ray diffraction with synchrotron radiation were obtained by a method similar to that for complex 1 (0.09 g, 68% based on Mo). Anal. calcd (%) for C21H33Cu3IMoN6S4·0.5C3H7NO: C 28.5, H 3.9, N 9.6; found: C 28.0, H 3.9, N 9.4.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [(MoS4Cu3I)2(bbd)3] n ⋅n(DMF), 3 

This compound was prepared in a manner similar to that for complex 2, but using (NH4)2[MoS4] (0.035 g, 0.14 mmol) instead of (NH4)2[WS4]. Very small, dark violet crystals of 3 suitable for X-ray diffraction with synchrotron radiation were obtained by a method similar to that for complex 1 (0.09 g, 68% based on Mo). Anal. calcd (%) for C21H33Cu3IMoN6S4⋅0.5C3H7NO: C 28.5, H 3.9, N 9.6; found: C 28.0, H 3.9, N 9.4.

elements.content: Single crystals of 1 and 2 were examined on an Oxford Diffraction (now Agilent Technologies) Gemini A Ultra diffractometer at 150 K, using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å) for 1 and Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for 2. In the case of 3, small crystal size required the use of synchrotron radiation (λ = 0.6889 Å), with a Crystal Logics kappa diffractometer and Rigaku Saturn 724+ CCD detector at beamline I19 of the Diamond Light Source, also at 150 K. Absorption corrections were semiempirical, based on repeated and symmetry-equivalent intensity measurements. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on all unique F 2 values. Hydrogen atoms were treated with a riding model after idealization of geometry; all other atoms were assigned anisotropic displacement parameters, which were subject to similarity and rigid-bond restraints in the case of light atoms of 2. Two-fold disorder of one bbd ligand in 3 was partially resolved by the refinement of alternative positions of the central CH2CH2 link, which lies on an inversion center, and highly disordered solvent was treated by the SQUEEZE procedure of PLATON. The largest residual electron density peaks in each structure lay close to the heavier atoms and are probably due mainly to imperfect absorption corrections. Selected crystallographic information is provided in Table . Other programs were standard Oxford Diffraction, Rigaku and Bruker APEX2 control and data processing software (including semiempirical absorption corrections based on repeated and symmetry-equivalent data), the Bruker SHELXTL suite for structure solution and refinement, and SHELXTL and Mercury for graphics.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single crystals of 1 and 2 were examined on an Oxford Diffraction (now Agilent Technologies) Gemini A Ultra diffractometer at 150 K, using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å) for 1 and Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for 2. In the case of 3, small crystal size required the use of synchrotron radiation (λ = 0.6889 Å), with a Crystal Logics kappa diffractometer and Rigaku Saturn 724+ CCD detector at beamline I19 of the Diamond Light Source, also at 150 K. Absorption corrections were semiempirical, based on repeated and symmetry-equivalent intensity measurements. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on all unique F 2 values. Hydrogen atoms were treated with a riding model after idealization of geometry; all other atoms were assigned anisotropic displacement parameters, which were subject to similarity and rigid-bond restraints in the case of light atoms of 2. Two-fold disorder of one bbd ligand in 3 was partially resolved by the refinement of alternative positions of the central CH2CH2 link, which lies on an inversion center, and highly disordered solvent was treated by the SQUEEZE procedure of PLATON. The largest residual electron density peaks in each structure lay close to the heavier atoms and are probably due mainly to imperfect absorption corrections. Selected crystallographic information is provided in Table . Other programs were standard Oxford Diffraction, Rigaku and Bruker APEX2 control and data processing software (including semiempirical absorption corrections based on repeated and symmetry-equivalent data), the Bruker SHELXTL suite for structure solution and refinement, and SHELXTL and Mercury for graphics.

We set out to investigate the influence of the molar ratio of copper(I) to [WS4]2– anion used in the synthesis, and the impact of the flexibility of the bbd ligand compared to the less flexible BpmMe2 ligand (Scheme ), on the stoichiometry and structural topology of the resultant heterometallic cluster complexes. The result is the generation of two novel one-dimensional polymeric complexes with different [WS4Cu n ] (n = 5, 3) cluster nodes (SBUs) from the reactions in DMF solution of (NH4)2[WS4], CuI and bbd in a molar ratio of 1:5:2 for 1 and 1:3:2 for 2. Complexes 1 and 2 are stable toward air and moisture. They are insoluble in common organic solvents such as acetone, MeCN, CH2Cl2, and CHCl3. Partial solubility in DMF and DMSO can be achieved with grinding. The complexes, together with 3, the molybdenum ananlogue of complex 2, have been characterized by elemental analyses, IR, UV–visible spectroscopy, thermal analyses, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of Complexes 1 and 2 

We set out to investigate the influence of the molar ratio of copper(I) to [WS4]2- anion used in the synthesis, and the impact of the flexibility of the bbd ligand compared to the less flexible BpmMe2 ligand (Scheme ), on the stoichiometry and structural topology of the resultant heterometallic cluster complexes. The result is the generation of two novel one-dimensional polymeric complexes with different [WS4Cu n ] (n = 5, 3) cluster nodes (SBUs) from the reactions in DMF solution of (NH4)2[WS4], CuI and bbd in a molar ratio of 1:5:2 for 1 and 1:3:2 for 2. Complexes 1 and 2 are stable toward air and moisture. They are insoluble in common organic solvents such as acetone, MeCN, CH2Cl2, and CHCl3. Partial solubility in DMF and DMSO can be achieved with grinding. The complexes, together with 3, the molybdenum ananlogue of complex 2, have been characterized by elemental analyses, IR, UV-visible spectroscopy, thermal analyses, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: While the respective molar ratios of CuI to [WS4]2– in the syntheses are retained in the stoichiometry of the two products, complex 1 incorporates the full amount of bbd ligand employed, while the ligand is depleted by one-quarter in complex 2, with only 1.5 rather than 2 ligand molecules per atom of W. It thus seems that the product stoichiometry is largely determined by the ratio of metal-containing reagents, which form the core SBUs, and not by any significant templating effect of the organic ligands. A 1:3:1 reaction stoichiometry leads to the discrete bbd-bridged double-cluster complex described already by Lang et al. and not to a polymer structure.

elements.content: The two structures reported here for the tungsten-containing complexes have a number of features in common but are different in detail. Both contain W–Cu–S clusters in which a tetrahedral WS4 core has some of its S···S edges bridged by Cu atoms, each of which is bonded to one or more I atoms. The clusters are linked by bbd bridges, with one N atom of each pyrazole ring coordinating to a Cu atom, generating chain polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 1 and 2 

The two structures reported here for the tungsten-containing complexes have a number of features in common but are different in detail. Both contain W-Cu-S clusters in which a tetrahedral WS4 core has some of its S⋅⋅⋅S edges bridged by Cu atoms, each of which is bonded to one or more I atoms. The clusters are linked by bbd bridges, with one N atom of each pyrazole ring coordinating to a Cu atom, generating chain polymers.

elements.content: The cluster in 1 is very unusual. It is derived from the parent thiometalate anion [WS4]2– by addition of Cu atoms to five of the six S···S edges. Four of the five Cu atoms lie in a plane, and each of these is coordinated by a nitrogen atom of a bbd bridging ligand, while the fifth Cu atom [Cu(2)] is coordinated only by S and I atoms (Figure ). The cluster may be considered as formed by two WS3Cu3I cube-like arrangements sharing a common WS2Cu face and with W and I atoms in opposite corners, but the two cubes differ significantly, in that one has 12 intact edges while the other has one edge broken: there is a considerable difference between the length of the Cu(2)–I(1) bond at 2.9412(19) Å and the unbonded Cu(2)···I(3) distance of 3.989 Å. While the cluster has crystallographic mirror symmetry across the plane containing W, Cu(2), I(2), S(1), and S(3), the disparity of Cu(2)–I(1) and Cu(2)···I(3) distances involves the loss of the second mirror plane (and 2-fold rotation axis in the W···Cu(2) direction) that could in principle be retained by bridging five of the six edges of the tetrahedral WS4 core. There is no obvious reason for this reduced symmetry, which reflects the wide range of strengths of Cu···halogen interactions found in MS4Cu n clusters containing halide ligands.

While the cluster has crystallographic mirror symmetry across the plane containing W, Cu(2), I(2), S(1), and S(3), the disparity of Cu(2)-I(1) and Cu(2)⋅⋅⋅I(3) distances involves the loss of the second mirror plane (and 2-fold rotation axis in the W⋅⋅⋅Cu(2) direction) that could in principle be retained by bridging five of the six edges of the tetrahedral WS4 core. There is no obvious reason for this reduced symmetry, which reflects the wide range of strengths of Cu⋅⋅⋅halogen interactions found in MS4Cu n  clusters containing halide ligands.

elements.content: As is commonly observed in such edge-bridged clusters with a WS4 (or MoS4) core, the parent WS4 unit retains essentially tetrahedral symmetry, with the two W–S bonds to μ4-S atoms slightly longer than the two to μ3-S atoms, and S–W–S angles close to the ideal 109.5°; the five W···Cu distances are all very similar and reflect the generally observed acute W–S–Cu angles rather than indicating any significant direct metal–metal bonding interactions. The five Cu atoms are all four-coordinate with distorted tetrahedral geometry. The four coplanar Cu atoms (two symmetry-equivalent pairs) each have an S2NI ligand set, while the unique Cu(2) is coordinated by two S and two I atoms. The three I atoms in the cluster all have different bonding environments: I(1) is bonded to three Cu atoms, I(3) to two, and I(2) to only one. There is a clear and expected trend in Cu–I bond lengths, with the shortest bond to terminal I(2) and the longest bonds to μ3-I(1). Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table .

Each WS4Cu5I3 cluster is linked to the next one in the polymeric chain structure by two bbd bridging ligands, generating a centrosymmetric 22-membered ring of C, N, Cu, and S atoms. The chain, with a repeat unit of one cluster and two bridging ligands (half a cluster and one ligand constitute the crystallographic asymmetric unit), runs along the b axis of the unit cell. The NCCCCN chain segment of the bbd ligand has two anti and one gauche torsion angles (sequence aag), setting the two pyrazole rings almost as far apart as possible so that the flexible bbd ligand adopts an almost fully extended conformation. The complete polymeric chain thus has a markedly folded zigzag shape (Figure ). Adjacent chains have no significant intermolecular interactions, and there are no pyrazole ring-stacking interactions within or between chains.

elements.content: The cluster unit in 2 is much simpler and more familiar (Figure ). Here three of the six S···S edges of the WS4 tetrahedron are bridged by Cu atoms. This may be done in two different ways, corresponding to fac and mer arrangements of three identical ligands in an octahedral complex, and 2 has the fac arrangement. This makes three of the four S atoms μ3, bonding to W and two Cu atoms each, and leaves the fourth S atom as a terminal ligand bonded only to W; as expected, this is the shortest W–S bond in the cluster. The W, three bridging S, and three Cu atoms form a distorted cube together with a single I atom, which occupies the corner of the cube opposite W and thus has three Cu–I bonds. The W atom retains a coordination geometry close to tetrahedral, while the Cu atoms are all four-coordinate, with distorted tetrahedral geometry and an S2NI ligand set, each being coordinated by a pyrazole N atom of a different bbd ligand. The complete cluster in 2 is thus WS4Cu3I, and the crystallographic asymmetric unit of the structure contains two of these clusters along with three bridging bbd ligands. While Cu–S and Cu–N bond lengths span relatively small ranges [2.252(3)–2.303(3) Å and 1.924(10)–1.969(9) Å respectively], there is considerably greater spread in the bonded Cu–I distances [2.9323(19)–3.3311(16) Å]; closer inspection shows that the μ3 bonding of I(1) is much more symmetrical (range < 0.05 Å) than that of I(2) (range almost 0.4 Å), which forms one long and two short bonds, tending slightly toward a μ2 situation like that found for I(3) in the cluster of complex 1. We have previously discussed the wide range of bonding asymmetry observed for I atoms in (O/S)MS3Cu3I pseudocubane clusters, and the degree of asymmetry found for I(2) here is much less extreme than in several other cases. It does, however, represent the most significant difference between the two crystallographically distinct clusters in the structure of 2. Selected bond lengths and angles for 2 are given in Table .

The two independent clusters in 2 are linked together by a pair of bridging bbd ligands, similar to the linking of adjacent clusters of 1, though these two bbd ligands are also crystallographically distinct from each other (Figure ). In this structure, the conformation of both of these ligands has the sequence agg for the saturated NCCCCN chain. As in the case of 1, a 22-membered ring of Cu, S, N, and C atoms is generated by the pair of bridging bbd ligands connecting two clusters. Here, however, the double-cluster/double-bridge units are further linked by only single bbd ligands to generate polymeric chains along the monoclinic c axis (Figure ). This third bbd ligand has a fully extended conformation with an aaa sequence for the NCCCCN chain and with the two pyrazole rings pointing in opposite directions, the ligand being approximately centrosymmetric overall.

elements.content: Although the WS4Cu3 cluster of 2 has a well-known shape, familiar in a considerable number of structures identified in a CSD search, this is actually the first reported example in which the cluster forms a polymeric structure with bridging organic ligands. In all previous cases, the cluster is part of a discrete, nonpolymeric structural unit. The other possible isomeric arrangement for WS4Cu3, in which the three Cu atoms are all coplanar with the W atom (a mer rather than a fac selection of three of the six S···S edges) and all four S atoms are involved in bonding to Cu atoms, by contrast, has been found in a number of polymeric structures with bridging organic ligands.

elements.content: In contrast to the structure of 1, significant pyrazole ring stacking interactions occur in 2; they are of two types. The conformations of the double bridges are such as to bring one ring of each ligand into close proximity and approximately parallel, with a centroid···centroid distance of 3.83 Å, an interplanar distance (defined as the perpendicular distance between one ring centroid and the mean plane of the other ring) of 3.51 Å, and a dihedral angle of 8.9° between the two rings. This is a ring-stacking interaction within chains. The other type of interaction is between adjacent chains and occurs for symmetry-equivalent pyrazole rings of the single bridges: both pyrazole rings of each single ring form such interactions, with the pairs of rings strictly parallel by symmetry in each case; the centroid···centroid distances are 3.64 and 3.76 Å, and the interplanar distances are 3.59 and 3.68 Å.

elements.content: We thus see in this pair of structures how the flexibility of the bbd ligand allows it to adopt different conformations with different overall lengths and different possible relative orientations of bonds formed by its donor N atoms with metal centers, enabling both single and double bridges to be formed between thiometalate cluster SBUs in polymeric chain structures. The flexibility of the bbd ligand may be considered as having two components: rotation about each of the three C–C single bonds in the saturated chain linking the two pyrazole rings, and rotation about the two N–C single bonds in the chain. Comparison of the results reported here and seven previous structures in which bbd (or its close relative without methyl substituents) serves as a bridge linking metal atoms shows that the choice of gauche and anti conformations for the C–C bonds provides some variation in the overall length of the bbd ligand as a bridge, while rotation about the N–C bonds provides the major contribution to the relative orientations of the two pyrazole rings and thus the directions of N–M donor bonds to metal atoms and the ability of bbd to bridge single metal atoms or clusters in discrete oligomeric or polymeric structures; this relative orientation of the rings is best described by the dihedral angle between their mean planes, expressed in the range 0–180° in order to distinguish arrangements in which the N–M donor bonds are convergent or divergent (two exactly parallel rings may have a dihedral angle of 0 or 180°, but in the former case the N–M bonds are parallel, while in the latter case they point in opposite directions). The nine available structures show no clear pattern in the anti/gauche sequences of torsion angles about C–C bonds (and the analysis is somewhat complicated by the incidence of disorder in some of the ligands), except that almost all single bridges, in contrast to pairs of bridges between neighboring metal atoms or clusters, are fully extended with a sequence aaa, while bridges that occur in pairs incorporate at least one gauche segment. The dihedral angle between pyrazole rings, on the other hand, can be readily categorized into three types of behavior. In all single bridges it lies close to 180°, having exactly this value in the majority of cases where the ligand lies on a crystallographic inversion center and 163° for the single bridge in complex 2. For ligands occurring in pairs between otherwise unconnected clusters the dihedral angle is 125° in 1 and 117° for both of the crystallographically independent bbd ligands forming the bridging pair in 2, indicating a divergent bridging geometry. However, when two clusters are linked by secondary Cu···halide interactions and are thus necessarily closer together, the paired bridges are convergent, with dihedral angles of 54°, 45°, and 46°. Such flexibility is not available to the Bp′ ligand, which is thus more restricted in its bridging behavior. Neither is it found in essentially linear bi- or poly pyridyl ligands used in the recent report of 3D MOFs with WS4Cu n clusters as SBUs.

elements.content: The reproducibility of the syntheses and the phase purity of the products were investigated by X-ray powder diffraction. For 1 the powder diffraction pattern was consistent with the structure obtained by single-crystal diffraction (full powder diffraction data are provided in the ). In the case of 2, however, the powder diffraction pattern showed at least one other material to be present in addition to that characterized by single-crystal diffraction, and repeated syntheses gave variable amounts of the products.
elements.clean_text:
Polymorphism of 2 and of Its Molybdenum Analogue 3 

The reproducibility of the syntheses and the phase purity of the products were investigated by X-ray powder diffraction. For 1 the powder diffraction pattern was consistent with the structure obtained by single-crystal diffraction (full powder diffraction data are provided in the ). In the case of 2, however, the powder diffraction pattern showed at least one other material to be present in addition to that characterized by single-crystal diffraction, and repeated syntheses gave variable amounts of the products.

elements.content: The best-formed crystals of complex 2 were those having the structure described in detail here, which we will denote 2A. In the case of complex 3 we obtained only very small crystals (typically <10 μm) but were eventually successful in measuring single-crystal diffraction data from one of these. Despite some problems with minor disorder of a bbd ligand and extensive disorder of solvent molecules, the crystal structure, denoted 3B, is of relatively high precision. It shows essentially the same polymeric chain structure as found for 2A, with only very small differences within the chains, but the chains are packed together with a different arrangement. The main differences in the two single-crystal structures are described here, and the full details for 3B are provided in the . Except for small differences in intensities and very small differences in peak positions arising from the substitution of Mo for W, which have different X-ray scattering powers and atomic radii, we are able to fit the observed powder diffraction patterns for complexes 2 and 3 to superpositions of scaled powder patterns calculated from the two single-crystal structures 2A and 3B, thus demonstrating that the two structures are concurrent polymorphs A and B of both Mo- and W-containing products 2 and 3 in the two synthetic procedures, which thus generate mixtures of 2A and 2B, and of 3A and 3B. This is consistent with the chemical analysis, spectroscopic and thermogravimetric measurements, which indicate chemical purity but give no information about polymorphism.

elements.content: The two polymorphs are both monoclinic, but with different space groups: P21/c for A and I2/a (an alternative setting of the conventional C2/c giving more nearly orthogonal axes and a more convenient comparison of the two structures) for B. The unit cell volumes are similar; the higher volume for B is consistent with larger solvent-accessible voids that are occupied by highly disordered DMF molecules in contrast to the ordered solvent molecules in A. Since the asymmetric unit of P21/c is one-quarter of the unit cell, while that of I2/a is one-eighth of the unit cell, but both structures have the same number of [(MS4Cu3I)2(bbd)3] chain repeat units in the cell, the asymmetric unit of A is one such repeat unit but the asymmetric unit of B is only half of it: in this case, there is just one unique cluster, the two bbd ligands linking them to form a ring are symmetry-equivalent, and the single bbd bridge lies across a crystallographic symmetry element. In fact, the cyclic (MS4Cu3I)2(bbd)2 unit has 2-fold rotation symmetry and the single bbd bridge has inversion symmetry in polymorph B, whereas this is only approximately the case in polymorph A (see Figure , where this approximate symmetry is apparent, the view being along the pseudorotation axis). The packing of the chains, together with the incorporation of DMF solvent molecules in appropriate small void spaces between them, retains these additional symmetry elements of I2/a in the complete crystal structure of B (involving disorder of DMF molecules across 2-fold rotation axes) but loses them in polymorph A (with ordered DMF molecules).

elements.content: In both polymorphs the chains run parallel to the c axis and display internal approximate (A) or exact (B) 2-fold rotation symmetry along the b axis; the two a axis lengths are very similar, but the b axis of B is approximately halved and its c axis is approximately doubled compared with A. These relationships are a consequence of packing arrangements for the two polymorphs that are different but involve the same kinds of interactions. In particular, both polymorphs involve π stacking of exactly parallel pyrazole rings in the single-link bbd ligands of adjacent chains: for polymorph B the unique centroid···centroid distance is 3.98 Å, and the interplanar distance is 3.45 Å (cf. 3.64/3.76 and 3.59/3.68 Å respectively in A as discussed previously). Clearly the energy differences between the polymorphs for both Mo- and W-containing complexes are very small, as both complexes are generated concurrently as two polymorphs in the syntheses, rather than favoring one or other of the structures.

elements.content: The infrared spectra of 1, 2 and 3 exhibit characteristic bands of the coordinated bbd ligands at 2925(m), 1552(s), 1468(s), 1420(m), and 1387(s) cm–1 and also typical absorption bands for ν(M–S) (M = W, Mo) stretching vibrations in the region 400–510 cm–1. The spectrum of 1 exhibits two adjacent bands with medium intensity at 452 and 436 cm–1, which are assigned to the stretching vibrations of the W−μ3-S and W−μ4-S bonds, respectively. In contrast, complexes 2 and 3 show two separate sharp bands at 435 and 501 cm–1 for 2, and at 442 and 514 cm–1 for 3, attributed to the M−μ3-S and terminal M–St stretching vibrations of the MS4 core, respectively. The ν(M−μ3-S) and ν(M−μ4-S) frequencies of the complexes are shifted to a lower frequency, while the ν(M–St) stretching frequency is shifted to a higher frequency, relative to those of the uncoordinated [MS4]2– anion (458 cm–1 for W and 480 cm–1 for Mo). These results are consistent with the structures of 1–3 determined by X-ray crystallography, which show that the [MS4]2– metalloligand is coordinated to the soft Cu(I) center through the sulfur atoms, as is usually the case. In addition, the IR spectra of crystals of 2 and 3 contain bands due to the presence of uncoordinated DMF solvent in the solid-state structures.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared and UV-Visible Spectroscopy

The infrared spectra of 1, 2 and 3 exhibit characteristic bands of the coordinated bbd ligands at 2925(m), 1552(s), 1468(s), 1420(m), and 1387(s) cm-1 and also typical absorption bands for ν(M-S) (M = W, Mo) stretching vibrations in the region 400-510 cm-1. The spectrum of 1 exhibits two adjacent bands with medium intensity at 452 and 436 cm-1, which are assigned to the stretching vibrations of the W-μ3-S and W-μ4-S bonds, respectively. In contrast, complexes 2 and 3 show two separate sharp bands at 435 and 501 cm-1 for 2, and at 442 and 514 cm-1 for 3, attributed to the M-μ3-S and terminal M-St stretching vibrations of the MS4 core, respectively. The ν(M-μ3-S) and ν(M-μ4-S) frequencies of the complexes are shifted to a lower frequency, while the ν(M-St) stretching frequency is shifted to a higher frequency, relative to those of the uncoordinated [MS4]2- anion (458 cm-1 for W and 480 cm-1 for Mo). These results are consistent with the structures of 1-3 determined by X-ray crystallography, which show that the [MS4]2- metalloligand is coordinated to the soft Cu(I) center through the sulfur atoms, as is usually the case. In addition, the IR spectra of crystals of 2 and 3 contain bands due to the presence of uncoordinated DMF solvent in the solid-state structures.

elements.content: The UV–visible absorption spectra of the freshly prepared samples of 1–3 were recorded from dilute DMF solutions and are shown in Figure . The spectra of the complexes display two broad bands with maxima at 435 and 312 nm for 1, at 427 and 304 nm for 2, and at 514 and 442 nm for 3, due to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer transitions within the MS4 unit. These bands are red-shifted relative to the free [MS4]2– anion (398 nm for W and 472 nm for Mo) and are affected by the local symmetry of this unit in the complexes. Comparison of the UV–visible spectra of the complexes 1 and 2 with their infrared spectra shows that, as the number of copper atoms bonded to the WS4 unit increases from 3 to 5, the electronic absorption bands shift to higher wavelengths and the ν(W–S) stretching vibrations move to lower wavenumbers. On the other hand, a red (bathochromic) shift of the absorption bands is observed, on going from W to corresponding Mo complexes. The size of the red shift depends on the nature of the complexes, and it must be recognized that the precise nature of the species in solution is not known, the solid-state polymeric structures assuredly being disrupted. However, their consistent shifts to higher wavelengths prove that the absorptions must arise from sulfur-to-metal charge-transfer transitions [S(π) → M(d)] and imply lower positioning of the vacant Mo 4d energy level relative to the W 5d orbitals.

elements.content: The thermal stability of the polymeric complexes was studied by TGA. As shown in Figure , a plateau in the temperature range 50–200 °C indicates that the architecture of complex 1 is stable up to 200 °C. The polymeric structure begins to collapse at about 215 °C with a weight loss of 32% up to 320 °C, consistent with the removal of two μ-bbd ligands per formula unit (calc 32.7%). Pyrolysis of the residual [WS4Cu5I3] units occurs in several stages at higher temperatures. For complex 2 the weight loss of 3.9% observed at 145–160 °C corresponds to the removal of the uncoordinated DMF (calc 3.6%). The decomposition of the complex begins at 180 °C with an observed mass loss of 38.8%, due to the removal of 1.5 bbd ligands per formula unit. As with 1, the residual [WS4Cu3I] units in 2 decompose in several stages up to 800 °C. For complex 3 the first weight loss occurs in the range 143–167 °C (obs 5.5%; calcd 4.8%) corresponding to the loss of the guest solvent molecules. The decomposition of the main structure occurs in the range 170–252 °C corresponding to the loss of one μ-bbd ligand per formula unit (obs 31.8%; calcd 30.5%). As with 1, the residual units in 2 and 3 decompose in several stages up to 800 °C.

elements.content: We have demonstrated facile syntheses of two new coordination polymers of WS4Cu n clusters (and one corresponding molybdenum complex) containing nonplanar hexanuclear (WCu5) and tetranuclear (WCu3) arrangements in which Cu atoms bridge five or three S···S edges of a WS4 tetrahedron, the Cu atoms then being coordinated by bridging and terminal iodo ligands and linked together by flexible bridging bbd ligands. In contrast to a recent publication in which the [WS4]2–:Cu(I) ratio was kept constant while other factors such as temperature, bridging ligand, and halide were varied (it is therefore surprising that the authors conclude that the stoichiometric ratio is less important than other factors in the synthesis), here the [WS4]2–:Cu(I) ratio was the only variable, maintaining the same solvent (DMF), halide (iodide), and bridging ligand (bbd). The one-pot reactions occurred in a short time and at room temperature, unlike solvothermal approaches. The chain polymeric structures of the two products do indeed reflect directly the W:Cu reagent stoichiometry, and they display novel features: the WS4Cu5I3 cluster unit in 1 is surprisingly unsymmetrical, containing three different modes of coordination by iodo ligands and lacking a 2-fold rotation axis and second mirror plane that might be expected for the overall shape of this cluster; 2 is the first reported case of a pseudocubane MS4Cu3X cluster (M = Mo or W, X = halogen) appearing in a polymeric structure with bridging organic ligands. Complex 2 and its molybdenum analogue 3 are always obtained in repeated syntheses as pairs of concurrent polymorphs A and B according to X-ray powder diffraction studies. The structure of the second polymorph of 3 (3B) has been determined; it has essentially the same polymer chain structure as the first polymorph as determined for 2 (2A), but a different packing arrangement of the chains. The bbd ligand is much more flexible than the polypyridyl and bis(pyrazolyl)methane (or -borate) ligands often used in such studies and can generate structures in which single metal atoms and thiometalate clusters are linked together in different ways to produce oligomeric or polymeric arrangements. By the choice of this and appropriate related flexible linker ligands, using other metals instead of Cu and other counterions, a wider range of (oxo)thiometalate central cores, and varying reaction stoichiometries, further interesting topological and geometrical structures should be accessible and can be targeted. Work is continuing in this area.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have demonstrated facile syntheses of two new coordination polymers of WS4Cu n  clusters (and one corresponding molybdenum complex) containing nonplanar hexanuclear (WCu5) and tetranuclear (WCu3) arrangements in which Cu atoms bridge five or three S⋅⋅⋅S edges of a WS4 tetrahedron, the Cu atoms then being coordinated by bridging and terminal iodo ligands and linked together by flexible bridging bbd ligands. In contrast to a recent publication in which the [WS4]2-:Cu(I) ratio was kept constant while other factors such as temperature, bridging ligand, and halide were varied (it is therefore surprising that the authors conclude that the stoichiometric ratio is less important than other factors in the synthesis), here the [WS4]2-:Cu(I) ratio was the only variable, maintaining the same solvent (DMF), halide (iodide), and bridging ligand (bbd). The one-pot reactions occurred in a short time and at room temperature, unlike solvothermal approaches. The chain polymeric structures of the two products do indeed reflect directly the W:Cu reagent stoichiometry, and they display novel features: the WS4Cu5I3 cluster unit in 1 is surprisingly unsymmetrical, containing three different modes of coordination by iodo ligands and lacking a 2-fold rotation axis and second mirror plane that might be expected for the overall shape of this cluster; 2 is the first reported case of a pseudocubane MS4Cu3X cluster (M = Mo or W, X = halogen) appearing in a polymeric structure with bridging organic ligands. Complex 2 and its molybdenum analogue 3 are always obtained in repeated syntheses as pairs of concurrent polymorphs A and B according to X-ray powder diffraction studies. The structure of the second polymorph of 3 (3B) has been determined; it has essentially the same polymer chain structure as the first polymorph as determined for 2 (2A), but a different packing arrangement of the chains. The bbd ligand is much more flexible than the polypyridyl and bis(pyrazolyl)methane (or -borate) ligands often used in such studies and can generate structures in which single metal atoms and thiometalate clusters are linked together in different ways to produce oligomeric or polymeric arrangements. By the choice of this and appropriate related flexible linker ligands, using other metals instead of Cu and other counterions, a wider range of (oxo)thiometalate central cores, and varying reaction stoichiometries, further interesting topological and geometrical structures should be accessible and can be targeted. Work is continuing in this area.

CuI (0.14 g, 0.72 mmol) was added to a yellow solution of (NH4)2[WS4] (0.05 g, 0.14 mmol) in DMF (15 mL). After being stirred for ca. 15 min, bbd (0.07 g, 0.28 mmol) was added to this solution, which was stirred for another 10 min at room temperature and filtered. Red single crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained from the freshly made sample in DMF, by leaving the filtrate to stand at room temperature for 2 days; they were collected and washed consecutively with small amounts of DMF, MeCN and Et2O, and dried in air (0.12 g, 57% based on W). Anal. calcd (%) for C28H44Cu5I3N8S4W: C 22.4, H 3.0, N 7.5; found: C 23.0, H 2.8, N 7.8.

CuI (0.08 g, 0.42 mmol) was added to a yellow solution of (NH4)2[WS4] (0.05 g, 0.14 mmol) in DMF (15 mL). After stirring for ca. 15 min, bbd (0.07 g, 0.28 mmol) was added to this solution, which was stirred for another 10 min at room temperature and filtered. Yellow-orange crystals of 2 were obtained by a method similar to that for complex 1 (0.09 g, 73% based on W). Anal. calcd (%) for C21H33Cu3IN6S4W·0.5C3H7NO: C 26.1, H 3.5, N 8.8; found: C 26.4, H 3.3, N 8.7.

Preparation of [(MoS<sub>4</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>I)<sub>2</sub>(bbd)<sub>3</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>·<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>(DMF), <bold>3</bold>

This compound was prepared in a manner similar to that for complex 2, but using (NH4)2[MoS4] (0.035 g, 0.14 mmol) instead of (NH4)2[WS4]. Very small, dark violet crystals of 3 suitable for X-ray diffraction with synchrotron radiation were obtained by a method similar to that for complex 1 (0.09 g, 68% based on Mo). Anal. calcd (%) for C21H33Cu3IMoN6S4·0.5C3H7NO: C 28.5, H 3.9, N 9.6; found: C 28.0, H 3.9, N 9.4.

Results and DiscussionSynthesis of Complexes <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold>

We set out to investigate the influence of the molar ratio of copper(I) to [WS4]2– anion used in the synthesis, and the impact of the flexibility of the bbd ligand compared to the less flexible BpmMe2 ligand (Scheme ), on the stoichiometry and structural topology of the resultant heterometallic cluster complexes. The result is the generation of two novel one-dimensional polymeric complexes with different [WS4Cu n ] (n = 5, 3) cluster nodes (SBUs) from the reactions in DMF solution of (NH4)2[WS4], CuI and bbd in a molar ratio of 1:5:2 for 1 and 1:3:2 for 2. Complexes 1 and 2 are stable toward air and moisture. They are insoluble in common organic solvents such as acetone, MeCN, CH2Cl2, and CHCl3. Partial solubility in DMF and DMSO can be achieved with grinding. The complexes, together with 3, the molybdenum ananlogue of complex 2, have been characterized by elemental analyses, IR, UV–visible spectroscopy, thermal analyses, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

cln_elements.content: The thermal stability of the polymeric complexes was studied by TGA. As shown in Figure , a plateau in the temperature range 50–200 °C indicates that the architecture of complex 1 is stable up to 200 °C. The polymeric structure begins to collapse at about 215 °C with a weight loss of 32% up to 320 °C, consistent with the removal of two μ-bbd ligands per formula unit (calc 32.7%). Pyrolysis of the residual [WS4Cu5I3] units occurs in several stages at higher temperatures. For complex 2 the weight loss of 3.9% observed at 145–160 °C corresponds to the removal of the uncoordinated DMF (calc 3.6%). The decomposition of the complex begins at 180 °C with an observed mass loss of 38.8%, due to the removal of 1.5 bbd ligands per formula unit. As with 1, the residual [WS4Cu3I] units in 2 decompose in several stages up to 800 °C. For complex 3 the first weight loss occurs in the range 143–167 °C (obs 5.5%; calcd 4.8%) corresponding to the loss of the guest solvent molecules. The decomposition of the main structure occurs in the range 170–252 °C corresponding to the loss of one μ-bbd ligand per formula unit (obs 31.8%; calcd 30.5%). As with 1, the residual units in 2 and 3 decompose in several stages up to 800 °C.

Thermal Analyses

The thermal stability of the polymeric complexes was studied by TGA. As shown in Figure , a plateau in the temperature range 50-200 °C indicates that the architecture of complex 1 is stable up to 200 °C. The polymeric structure begins to collapse at about 215 °C with a weight loss of 32% up to 320 °C, consistent with the removal of two μ-bbd ligands per formula unit (calc 32.7%). Pyrolysis of the residual [WS4Cu5I3] units occurs in several stages at higher temperatures. For complex 2 the weight loss of 3.9% observed at 145-160 °C corresponds to the removal of the uncoordinated DMF (calc 3.6%). The decomposition of the complex begins at 180 °C with an observed mass loss of 38.8%, due to the removal of 1.5 bbd ligands per formula unit. As with 1, the residual [WS4Cu3I] units in 2 decompose in several stages up to 800 °C. For complex 3 the first weight loss occurs in the range 143-167 °C (obs 5.5%; calcd 4.8%) corresponding to the loss of the guest solvent molecules. The decomposition of the main structure occurs in the range 170-252 °C corresponding to the loss of one μ-bbd ligand per formula unit (obs 31.8%; calcd 30.5%). As with 1, the residual units in 2 and 3 decompose in several stages up to 800 °C.
